stream_context.summary: Kaze spent most of the session continuing Course 15’s "space" path: importing flying taxi models, building a parking-lot platform set, adding a gramophone with piano-key stairs, and roughing in a retro-futuristic CRT prop. He also debugged crashes linked to excess collision nodes, tested on several emulators, and discussed plans for future videos and releases.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wants to ship two builds: (1) a pure N64 ROM hack and (2) a PC/Steam version produced by static recompilation with every Nintendo asset and remaining Mario 64 code removed to avoid legal risk.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking maybe using the static recompilation to release this game both like as an N64 game with Mario and officially as a game on Steam… Obviously, I would replace all Nintendo assets and would kick out the last bit of Nintendo code as well.

development_findings.summary: Current work focused on Course 15’s traversal: flying cars are stationary platforms; a taxi parking lot adds height variety; gramophone, microphone, and piano-key stairs act as climbable geometry toward a black-hole goal.
Design philosophy keeps core Mario 64 movement intact; new set-pieces shouldn’t ‘take the base movement away’ from players.
development_findings.quote: I don't like to take the base Mario 64 movement away from the player too much.

development_findings.summary: Hub World will recreate the entire Yoshi’s Island, finished last so level entrances and secrets can be placed after all courses are defined; Kaze expects ‘more secret levels than the original.’
development_findings.quote: The hub world will be so full of secrets. I was thinking of maybe adding more secret levels than the original game had.

development_findings.summary: Movement tweak: the dive now allows mid-air direction change only if speed is forfeited—adopted after testers disliked a full lock.
development_findings.quote: People hated it… so I made it so you can change the direction when you lose your speed now, and people seem to be more willing to accept that.

development_findings.summary: Engine optimisation cycle: Kaze intentionally ‘ruins’ the game for speed, then fixes bugs; he is battling crashes caused by too many collision surface nodes and excess triangles.
development_findings.quote: My dev process is… take the game, ruin it, but make it more optimized, and then fix the bugs.

development_findings.summary: Possible Kickstarter is on hold; Kaze fears complicated sales-tax laws could ‘completely fuck’ the project.
development_findings.quote: I'm scared of using Kickstarter because of sales-tax laws. I don't understand how they work with Kickstarter and I'm kind of scared of getting completely fucked.

development_findings.summary: External artists must understand N64 limits; otherwise onboarding time outweighs benefit. Kaze is reluctant to pay unless contributors already know the pipeline.
development_findings.quote: I'm a little worried I'm gonna have to spend so much time teaching him that he ends up costing more time than he saves… unfortunately that happens fairly frequently.

development_findings.summary: Potential boss concept ‘Octoyoshi’: Biobak suggested a black-hole-dwelling Yoshi with tentacles and internal ‘tumors’ the player heals by entering its mouth.
Ares (cycle-accurate) emulator is now part of his test stack alongside real hardware, NEMU, Project 64, and Parallel, aiding performance debugging.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is preparing for a Canadian citizenship test in ~5 months and repeatedly states he does not want to return to Germany, calling it ‘hell’.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to be in Germany. Germany is hell.

context_findings.summary: He describes video production as exhausting but necessary for algorithm visibility; he is editing his ‘longest video yet’ about Mario 64 shaders.
context_findings.quote: Making that video makes me feel so sick. It's so much work and so exhausting. I keep making videos.

context_findings.summary: Financial constraints: cannot currently afford to commission new character art; volunteers are welcome, paid work unlikely.
context_findings.quote: I don't really have the money to commission random people, but I would absolutely like to get work done for this game.

context_findings.summary: Work–life reflections: in university he isolated himself to work on ROM hacking, calling it ‘the loneliest possible college experience’ and advising against it.
context_findings.quote: That is not good for your mental health and I don't recommend anyone does that.

context_findings.summary: Paranoia about data loss: he backs up to Git every time he leaves the house, fearing hardware failure or break-ins.
context_findings.quote: Whenever I leave my house I backup everything. That's what I use Git for.

biobak.summary: Currently reworking Course 2 graphics; provided concept art and gameplay feedback for the proposed Octoyoshi boss, noting earlier version felt ‘too cryptic.’

zeina.summary: Zeina created shy-guy NPC concept art for the space city and remains an artistic contributor.
Gifted memberships in chat and playful banter highlight healthy personal/professional dynamic.

key_stories.title: The Volunteer Artist Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Many artists offer help but lack N64-specific technical knowledge. Kaze worries onboarding them costs more time than it saves.
key_stories.challenge: Need additional graphics while staying within budget.
key_stories.process: Evaluates offers; explains shader and pipeline restrictions; recalls past experiences where teaching volunteers consumed development time.
key_stories.outcome: Currently declines most paid commissions, accepts only volunteers who already understand N64 constraints.
key_stories.key_quote: They end up needing a bunch of introduction and end up not actually producing anything for the game.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Dive Controversy
key_stories.summary: A mechanical change removing mid-air directional control during dives angered testers. Kaze adjusted the compromise to keep control but drop speed.
key_stories.process: Tested a full lock, gathered feedback, implemented speed-loss variant, re-tested.
key_stories.outcome: New behaviour accepted by community, retained in latest build.
key_stories.key_quote: People hated it… so I made it so you can change the direction when you lose your speed now.

key_stories.title: Conceiving Octoyoshi
key_stories.summary: Kaze and Biobak brainstorm a late-game boss: a tentacled Yoshi emerging from black holes, with tumors the player must heal.
key_stories.challenge: Original Yoshi boss idea felt cryptic and unsatisfying.
key_stories.process: Biobak offered new concept art and attack pattern ideas; Kaze discussed integrating mouth-interior gameplay and antenna attacks.
key_stories.outcome: Concept accepted for further design work; not yet modelled.
key_stories.key_quote: He attacks out of black holes… maybe you have to jump into his mouth and destroy the tumors inside.

key_stories.title: Planning a Legal PC Release
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants a wider audience but must avoid Nintendo IP violations.
key_stories.challenge: Releasing commercially without infringing Nintendo copyrights.
key_stories.process: Explored static recompilation, outlined removal of Mario assets and remaining code, rejected idea of launching ‘Mario’ on Steam as ‘insanity.’
key_stories.outcome: Strategy tentatively set: dual release (N64 + PC) with wholly original branding.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm not just going to release a Mario game on Steam. That would literally be insanity.
